fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M be an NFA\varepsilon ; then \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

We must show that any string u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} lies in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

If u=\epsilon , then we have assumed that s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }q such that q\in F_{M}; therefore, by definition, we have q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}. Thus we have q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\cap F_{M} and so it follows by definition that s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}.
Suppose that u=a_1\cdots a_n, and so we have transitions s_{M}\xRightarrow {a_1}q_1\xRightarrow {\cdots } q_{n-1}\xRightarrow {a_n}q_n with q_n\in F_{M}.
We inductively define a sequence of states S_i in \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} as follows:
Define q_0=s_{M}. Then for all 0\leq i \leq n, we observe that we have q_i\in S_i.

We proceed by induction on i. For i=0, we need s_{M}\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}; but this holds by definition. Next, assuming q_i\in S_i we must show that q_{i+1}\in S_{i+1} = \delta _{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}{\mathopen {}\left (S_i,a_{i+1}\right )\mathclose {}}. Unfolding definitions, this follows from the transition q_i\xRightarrow {a_{i+1}} q_{i+1} that we have assumed, as our inductive hypothesis ensures q_i\in S_i.

It follows from the above that we have transitions S_0=s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {a_1}S_1\xrightarrow {\cdots }S_{n-1}\xrightarrow {a_n}S_n. Becuase we have shown q_n\in S_n and we have assumed q_n\in F_{M}, we have S_n\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}. Thus it follows that \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} accepts u.

fr:title.text: The subset construction: equivalence of NFA\varepsilon s with DFAs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subset construction: equivalence of NFA\varepsilon s with DFAs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Although very few NFA\varepsilon s are NFAs and very few of those are DFAs, all these kinds of automata nonetheless generate the same classes of formal languages. In the upward direction, it is easy to see that any DFA is also an NFA with a deterministic and total transition relation, and moreover any NFA is an NFA\varepsilon with an empty \varepsilon -transition relation, and that the formal languages induced by all these agree. Conversely, it is much less obvious that we can go the other direction, i.e. that we can associate to a given NFA\varepsilon an NFA or a DFA that accepts the same formal language. That is the purpose of the subset construction which we shall study in this section.
Let M be an NFA\varepsilon over an alphabet \Sigma ; we define an DFA \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} over \Sigma called the subset construction of M as follows:

html:ol.html:li: We define the set of states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} to be the powerset of the set of states of M. Q_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} = \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (Q_{M}\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{S\,\middle \vert \,S\subseteq Q_{M}\right \}\mathclose {}}

The starting state of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is the set of states reachable by any number of \varepsilon -transitions from the starting state of M, i.e. the set of states reachable from s_{M} via the empty string: s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{q\in Q\,\middle \vert \,s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q\right \}\mathclose {}}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In order to get a thorough intuition for the subset construction we will see how it acts on a sample NFA\varepsilon M over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} which we draw below:

html:figure.html:figcaption: A sample NFA\varepsilon M over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}, where \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}={\mathopen {}\left \{a^mb^n\right \}\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (a{*}b{*}\right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} are all the subsets of Q_{M}:
The starting state of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is the set of states reachable from q_0 via the empty string:
The accepting states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} are all the sets of states containing an accepting state of M:
We then describe the transition function of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} by means of a table:
All in all, we have the following DFA:
As you can see, the resulting DFA is kind of strange and has many redundant states. But it does accept the desired language.

The goal of Definition is to transform an NFA\varepsilon M into a DFA \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} that accepts the same language, i.e. that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}. We prove this in two steps below.

Let M be an NFA\varepsilon ; then \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}.

We must show that any string u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} lies in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}.

If u=\epsilon , then by definition we have s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} and so by definition, there exists q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} such that q\in F_{M}. By definition of s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}, we therefore have s\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q; because q\in F_{M}, we have \epsilon \in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}.

Suppose on the other hand that u=a_1\cdots a_n, and so we therefore have transitions s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a_1}}S_1\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\ldots }}S_{n-1}\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a_n}}S_n with S_n\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}, and so there exists some q_n\in S_n\cap F_{M}. Define S_0 = s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}.

By definition of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}, from the transition S_{n-1}\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a_n}}S_n we may find some q_{n-1}\in S_{n-1} such that q_{n-1}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {a_n}}q_n. Iterating this process, we may find states q_i\in S_{i} such that we have a sequence of transitions q_{i-1}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {a_i}}q_i in M; thus we have a sequence of transitions q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}}q_n. Because q_0\in S_0=s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}, we have s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q_0 and thus s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}}q_n and therefore s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}} q_n. Because q_n\in F_{M}, we are done.

Let M be an NFA\varepsilon ; then \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

We must show that any string u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} lies in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

If u=\epsilon , then we have assumed that s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }q such that q\in F_{M}; therefore, by definition, we have q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}. Thus we have q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\cap F_{M} and so it follows by definition that s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}.
Suppose that u=a_1\cdots a_n, and so we have transitions s_{M}\xRightarrow {a_1}q_1\xRightarrow {\cdots } q_{n-1}\xRightarrow {a_n}q_n with q_n\in F_{M}.
We inductively define a sequence of states S_i in \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} as follows:
Define q_0=s_{M}. Then for all 0\leq i \leq n, we observe that we have q_i\in S_i.

We proceed by induction on i. For i=0, we need s_{M}\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}; but this holds by definition. Next, assuming q_i\in S_i we must show that q_{i+1}\in S_{i+1} = \delta _{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}{\mathopen {}\left (S_i,a_{i+1}\right )\mathclose {}}. Unfolding definitions, this follows from the transition q_i\xRightarrow {a_{i+1}} q_{i+1} that we have assumed, as our inductive hypothesis ensures q_i\in S_i.

It follows from the above that we have transitions S_0=s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {a_1}S_1\xrightarrow {\cdots }S_{n-1}\xrightarrow {a_n}S_n. Becuase we have shown q_n\in S_n and we have assumed q_n\in F_{M}, we have S_n\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}. Thus it follows that \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} accepts u.

fr:title.text: Equivalence between NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence between NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs all generate the same class of languages.

In Lemma and Lemma , we have proved that NFA\varepsilon s and DFAs generate the same class of language as any NFA\varepsilon can be converted into a DFA recognising the same language. As any NFA is in particular an NFA\varepsilon , we see that NFAs are equivalent to DFAs in the same sense.

fr:title.text: Lecture 22: finite automata › Optional material › Alternative definition of F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lecture 22: finite automata › Optional material › Alternative definition of F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Why can’t we define F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} to be the set of singletons {\mathopen {}\left \{q\right \}\mathclose {}} such that q\in F_{M}?

Because if we did, then Lemma would fail already in the case of the empty string. We would have s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }{q} with q\in F_{M} and thus q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}; we would need s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} and with the proposed definition, this would need to be a singleton. There is, however, nothing about our assumptions that allows us to deduce that and, indeed, we can certainly come up with examples where s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} is not a singleton (e.g. if we have \epsilon -transitions of the form s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }q for q\not = s_{M}).
Let M be an NFA\varepsilon over an alphabet \Sigma ; we define an DFA \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} over \Sigma called the subset construction of M as follows:

html:ol.html:li: We define the set of states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} to be the powerset of the set of states of M. Q_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} = \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (Q_{M}\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{S\,\middle \vert \,S\subseteq Q_{M}\right \}\mathclose {}}

The starting state of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is the set of states reachable by any number of \varepsilon -transitions from the starting state of M, i.e. the set of states reachable from s_{M} via the empty string: s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{q\in Q\,\middle \vert \,s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q\right \}\mathclose {}}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A non-deterministic finite automaton with \varepsilon -transitions or NFA\varepsilon for short is an NFA M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} together with an additional relation T\colon Q\mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the \varepsilon -transition relation.

We will write q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' to mean that q\mathrel {T}q'. This notation is a little confusing! Note that this \varepsilon is not the same as the \epsilon denoting the empty string, and that therefore q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' means something very different from q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}\smash {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}^*} q'.
We have already seen some inductive definitions:

html:ul.html:li: Definition defines n-fold iterations of endo-relations by induction on n.
Algorithm computes the adjacency matrix of the reflexive-transitive closure of a finite directed graph by induction on the number of vertices in the graph.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In this section, we will study this concept in more detail.

fr:title.text: Informal examples of inductively defined functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Informal examples of inductively defined functions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An inductive definition on the naturals defines a structure for each number n\in \mathbb {N} by first defining it for n=0 and then specifying how to augment a structure for n=m to a structure for n=m+1. From the point of view of computer programming, inductive definitions proceed by structural recursion. For example, addition of natural numbers can be defined by induction on the second argument (or the first, if you prefer!):
Likewise, the function \Sigma \colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} that takes n\in \mathbb {N} to the sum \sum _{0\leq i < n}i can be defined inductively:
In order to make precise the description of Definition , Algorithm , and Example as “inductive definitions”, we must give an actual formal definition of what an inductive definition is.

Let A be a set, and fix a\in A and f\colon \mathbb {N}\times A\to A. The function inductively defined from a and f is defined to be the unique function \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\to A satisfying the following equations:

Note that our specification of inductively defined functions in Definition asserts, without proof, that there does in fact exist a unique function \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\to A satisfying the described equations. It is not blindingly obvious that this claim is true — and, after seeing a few examples to motivate Definition , we will explicitly justify Definition by means of an existence theorem.

fr:title.text: Formal examples of inductively defined functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal examples of inductively defined functions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have seen two informal examples of inductive definitions in Example ; we will now update these examples in light of Definition :

html:ul.html:li: For every m\in \mathbb {N}, function \mathsf {add}{\mathopen {}\left (m,-\right )\mathclose {}}\colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} is the function \mathbf {\rho }_{m,{\mathopen {}\left (i,n\right )\mathclose {}}\mapsto n+1} inductively defined by m\in \mathbb {N} and f{\mathopen {}\left (i,n\right )\mathclose {}} = n+1.

The function \Sigma \colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} taking n\in \mathbb {N} to \sum _{0\leq i<n}i is the function \mathbf {\rho }_{0,\mathsf {add}} inductively defined by 0\in \mathbb {N} and \mathsf {add}\colon \mathbb {N}\times \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given an element a\in A and a function f\colon \mathbb {N}\times A \to A, we call a relation R\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed whenever we have both 0\mathrel {R}a and n\mathrel {R}x\implies {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {R}f{\mathopen {}\left (n,x\right )\mathclose {}} for all n\in \mathbb {N} and x\in A.

In light of Definition , we see that Definition is defining \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f} to be the unique {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed function. We still have to show that this exists.

Given an element a\in A and a function f\colon \mathbb {N}\times A\to A, now let \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A be the intersection of all the {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed relations R\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A.

html:ol.html:li: The relation \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is functional and total, and therefore a function.

The function \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\to A is the unique {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed function, i.e. it is the unique function satisfying both \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{\mathopen {}\left (0\right )\mathclose {}}=a and \forall n\in \mathbb {N}\mathpunct {.} \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}=f{\mathopen {}\left (n,\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{n}\right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We first notice that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is itself {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed, which can be seen by observing that the intersection of a set of {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed relations is {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed. With this in hand, we proceed.

html:li.html:p: We must show that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is a function.

html:ol.html:li:
To show that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is functional, we must show that for all n\in \mathbb {N} and x,y\in A, if n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}} x and n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}y, then x=y. We proceed to prove P{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}} = \forall x,y\in A\mathpunct {.} n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}} x \land n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}y\implies x=y by induction on n\in \mathbb {N}.
For the base case, we fix x,y\in A such that 0\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}x and 0\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}} y to check that x=y. By definition, we know that for any {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed relation R\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A we both 0\mathrel {R}x and 0\mathrel {R}y.
We choose R be the union of {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left (0,a\right )\mathclose {}}\right \}\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left (n,x\right )\mathclose {}}\,\middle \vert \,n > 0 \land n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}} x\right \}\mathclose {}}, which is {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed; we have used the fact that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f} is {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed. As this union is disjoint, we can see that 0\mathrel {R}z if and only if z=a, so we have x=a=y.
In the inductive step, we assume P{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}} to prove P{\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}. Fixing x,y\in A such that {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}x and {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}y, we must show that x=y.
We know that for any {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed relation R\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A we have both {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {R}x and {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {R}y.
We choose R to be the union of {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left (m+1,f{\mathopen {}\left (m,z\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\,\middle \vert \,m=n\land m\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}{z}\right \}\mathclose {}} with {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left (m,z\right )\mathclose {}}\,\middle \vert \,m\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}z\land m\not =n+1\right \}\mathclose {}}, noting that R is {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed because \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f} is {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed. As the union defining R is disjoint, for any z\in A we know that {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {R}z if and only if z=f{\mathopen {}\left (n,z'\right )\mathclose {}} for some z' with n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}} z'.
Therefore, we have some x',y'\in A such that x=f{\mathopen {}\left (n,x'\right )\mathclose {}} and y=f{\mathopen {}\left (n,y'\right )\mathclose {}} and n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}} x' and n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}y'. By our inductive hypothesis, we know that x'=y', and hence x=y.

html:li.html:p: To show that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } A is total, we must show that for every n\in \mathbb {N}, we have \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow }. This is proved by induction on n\in \mathbb {N}:

html:ol.html:li: In the base case, we deduce \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{\mathopen {}\left (0\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow } from our asumption that 0\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}a.

In the inductive step, we assume that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow } and must show that \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow }. By our assumption, we have n\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}{{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}}}; because \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f} is {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed relation, we may conclude {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathrel {\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}}f{\mathopen {}\left (n,\mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\right )\mathclose {}}.

It remains to show that the function \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f}\colon \mathbb {N}\to A is the unique {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closed function. This too can be proved by induction, as functionality and {\mathopen {}\left (a,f\right )\mathclose {}}-closure fully specify the values of \mathbf {\rho }_{a,f} on all inputs.
